Sup normies. Some of you may be confused with the Gilgamesh memes so here’s an explanation.


It’s centered around the Fate Series consisting of Visual Novels, MULTIPLE Anime seasons, and more Anime spin offs.

Anyways, the main theme is that they incorporate historical characters/figures (both true to life & mythical) and gender swap them (i.e. King Arthur is a female knight) before sending them into a Battle Royale of pairs of Summoners (humans) & Servants (the historical figures summoned).

The chicken dinner is the Holy Grail that grants any wish you desire (1 for the summoner & 1 for the servant) but it requires mana to work.

Each series has its own theme

1) Fate Series - Battle Royale for Holy Grail either in near past or present day
2) Ilyria spin off - Magical lolis just adventuring in present day Japan
3) Grand Order spin off - Coop against a bad guy who has the Holy Grail in 7 different timelines

Gilgamesh Immortal wild born wore lion skins
till tamed by the priestess Ishtar
Great Sage and Warrior defeated mortality
the unceasing tyranny of Time


Invincible Conqueror he first captured Uruk
then even to Lebanon on the Middle Sea shore
Sumer's great gods he brought and smashed idols
his glories are carved in permanent rock


Gilgamesh Emperor refused his mortality
challenged this affronting curtailment of power
He curses the gods who gave mankind death
and kept immortality themselves


He desecrates the temples dismantles the altars
discredits the ancient beliefs
Then Gilgamesh wanders again wearing lion skins
searching for everlasting life


But he cannot claim one hundred years
or even five days in this world
till Sleep gently takes to her restful abode
the great warrior docile and blind


Eternity is found in the cavernous dark
excess time too great to endure
Is this then my fate or will I cease to be
Gilgamesh resolves to inquire


The answer he learns as sailors well know
lies on the deep ocean floor
But that bitter truth encased in sharp spines
has never been brought back to shore


Undaunted the sage who searched beyond heaven
for the secret to undying youth
ties rocks to his feet descends through the deep
poised at the threshold of death


Gilgamesh plucks and swallows the fruit
too thorny for mortals to hold
Then returning to Uruk reigned fifty more years
devoted and caring for all


Ninety-nine years was his time on this earth
after ninety-nine years and nine days
maggots appeared a great stench arose
his corpse was consigned to the flames


His funeral remembered for eighty four years
was portrayed in gold and bright stones
The shrine was revered for five hundred more
then plundered and levelled by foe


But Gilgamesh Immortal has no need of monuments
from clay to papyrus he strides
From parchment to print and digital media
technologies yet to arrive


Ripples arise in the seething entropy
multitudes exist and subside
Five thousand years and all that has passed
Gilgamesh alone survives.

Well, you see, Norm, it’s like this. A herd of buffalo can only move as fast as the slowest buffalo. And when the herd is hunted, it’s the slowest and weakest ones at the back that are killed first. This natural selection is good for the herd as a whole, because the general speed and health of the whole group keeps improving by the regular killing of the weakest members. In much the same way, the human brain can only operate as fast as the slowest brain cells. Now, as we know, excessive intake of alcohol kills brain cells. But naturally, it attacks the slowest and weakest brain cells first. In this way, regular consumption of beer eliminates the weaker brain cells, making the brain a faster and more efficient machine.

And that, Norm, is why you always feel smarter after a few beers.

I'm a Sumerologist and just want to clear a few things up:
1) it's called "Sumer", not "Sumeria"
2) The oldest Gilgamesh story in text form we have is from ca. 2700 BCE; also, the Sumerian Gilgamesh (semiticised from Bilgames) is a different collection of stories than the later Babylonian ones, with a very different emphasis.
3) The 2/3 deity thing can be calculated when considering that his father, Lugalbanda, is also of divine descent (Sun god).
4) It's a cedar forest that Gilgamesh and Enkidu wander into to kill the guardian of the forest. They did that because Gilgamesh wanted the wood, as Mesopotamia is more or less resources-free.
5) The reason Shamash helps is because he is related to Gilgamesh.
6) Siduri is not the goddess of beer and wisdom. That would be Ninkasi.
7) Lovely choice of images, but from a professional perspective it's all a bit of a jumble.
8) You are forgetting the beginning and the end. Gilgamesh in the Standard Babylonian version begins, after the beautiful words "He Who Saw the Deep", with a description of the city of Uruk, particularly its wall and quarters and gardens. At the end, when he returns from Ūta-napištim, he is accompanied by the ferryman. They arrive at Uruk, and Gilgamesh is proud to show the foreigner his city, and the same words are used. It's the focus on what man can achieve if he is okay with being, well, man. This is also echoed in Siduri's words to Gilgamesh, reminding him of the things that are human: falling in love, laughing, raising a child and living on forever through your work and offspring.

By 1898-1899 Professor Jastrow Morris Junior, of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, had proposed in academic journals of that time that Enkidu (his Eabani) had been recast as Adam and his seducer, Shamhat (his Ukhat), the temple prostitute of Uruk, had been recast as Eve (Scholars circa 1898 knew the Epic of Gilgamesh as the Epic of Izdubar). Morris was a trained reader of Sumerian and Akkadian (Babylonian ) cuneiform. His contemporary, Professor Archibald Henry Sayce, of Oxford University, England, who was also trained in reading Sumerian and Akkadian, argued in 1892 that Adapa of Adapa and the Southwind myth, had been recast as Adam in the biblical book of Genesis. By 1881 a German Professor, who could read Sumerian and Akkadian, Friedrich Heinrich Delitzsh, of the University of Leipzig, had noted that Sumer's Edin (the uncultivated wilderness land surrounding Sumerian cities) was probably the pre-biblical source of Genesis' 'Eden. I find myself in agreement with all of three of these professors. I have written two books on the subject and they are available ($25.00 each) at Amazon.com, Walter R. Mattfeld, Eden's Serpent: Its Mesopotamian Origin (2010) and The Garden of Eden Myth: Its Pre-biblical Origin in Mesopotamian Myths (2010). The Hebrews apparently recast the Mesopotamian myths about events associated with polytheism's Edin into a monotheistic Eden. Professor George's hardback 2 volume work on Gilgamesh is expensive, costing almost $1,000.00. His much cheaper paperback version of the Epic can be had for under $20.00 (published by Penquin books in England). George's two volume work was useful to me in that George's translation of the Epic revealed that Enkidu meets Shamhat in a wilderness called Edin, at a watering hole frequented by him and his companions, wild bulls and antelope. He is naked like they are, and is accepted as their companion. Shamhat has been brought to Edin's watering-hole (note George renders edin in his paperback book by Penquin publishers as "wilderness" or "field") to replace Enkidu's animal companions with herself as his new companion. She is instructed by the hunter to convince Enkidu to leave Edin (Edin is a Sumerian logogram substitute for Akkadian Seri/seru, "wilderness" or "field" according to Professor George) and take up residence in Uruk (rendered in Akkadian cuneiform by the Sumerian logogram Unug). She succeeds. Both have sex with each other for several days, when he attempts to rejoin his animal companions they flee from him, rejecting him, he thereupon returns to Shamhat who praises him for returning to her. He now accepts her as his new companion. She convinces him to leave Edin/Seru. Before leaving they clothe their nakedness with her clothes. In route to Uruk (Unug) they encounter a shepherd's camp. They offer him bread and beer. He refuses to consume these items for he knows only to eat grass and drink water with his animal companions in Edin. Shamhat, realizing the problem, intercedes and urges him to consume these products and he obeys her. Edin's shepherds whereupon announce Enkidu is no longer a naked wild animal, he has become like a god, consuming food set aside for the gods, bread and beer, they give him a fine robe fit for a king to wear, to cover his nakedness, the woman's garb not being suitable for a man to wear. The bread and beer Enkidu refused to consume became in Genesis Adam's fruit of death from Eden's tree. Shamhat's being brought to Edin by the hunter to ensnare Enkidu and remove him from Edin and its animals, was recast as God bringing Eve to Adam as a more fit companion than Eden's beasts. The hunter brought Shamhat to Edin's watering hole to remove Enkidu who was setting free Edin's wild animals from the hunter's traps. If you're interested in Gilgamesh, try going back a few thousand more years & read about Inanna.  It's in her story that the story of Gilgamesh sprouted & grew, so you can see the "birth" & formation of the Gilgamesh saga from another point of view. Inanna is a very ancient deity, created the first laws (called "holy me's")(long before Hammurabi), & the first hymn signed by it's creator is a hymn to Inanna (signed by a woman named Enheduanna). Gilgamesh started out as a minor player in the stories about Inanna, & he didn't even show up in that "bit player" role until towards the end of the culture that worshiped Inanna.  His name is not even mentioned in earliest myths, hymns & stories about her.

The first chapters of Genesis in the Hebrew/Christian bible heavily borrow from those stories. They even kept the plural form when Elohim talk to him/them self because in the original Mesopotamian text, the Gods are talking to each other that way. This is easy to read in the Hebrew bible, but the translators hide these details for fear to confuse people.

There is no debate in the Jewish community about science and the stories in Genesis. They know how to interpret them, it is not the "literal words of God", but simple just imaginary stories. Adam, Noah are known to be symbolic heroes like we all know Santa Claus or spider man.
